title: Overview
content:
Aside from the firmware, the application consists of 3 parts:
 flowcontrol flowcontrol-monitor flowcontrol-cli  flowcontrol and flowcontrol-cli are currently independent, I’m looking to consolidate their codebase now they’re both using Go and utilise shared packages for stuff like serial communication.
flowcontrol This is the GUI application. It’s built using wails
flowcontrol-monitor This is the supplementary application to the main one. It provides system metrics such as GPU Clock and temperatures using LibreHardwareMonitorLib. I’m aiming to make this an optional component for people who want hardware metrics beyond the scope of the controller, it’s currently bundled with the release.
flowcontrol-cli A CLI application built using cobra

title: Desktop App
content: Prerequisites  Go 1.12+ npm net5 SDK (Optional, only required if you’re using the monitor)  Linux  gcc, gtk, webkitgtk  Running Locally flowcontrol cd src/flowcontrol/ wails serve cd src/flowcontrol/frontend npm run serve flowcontrol-monitor cd src/flowcontrol-monitor/ dotnet run

title: Requirements
content:
Parts List Here’s a list of parts you’ll need if you’d like to build the hardware yourself:
 USB to UART module Raspberry Pi Pico x2 4-Pin PWM Fan Connector Male x2 10k Resistors x2 Female and Male JST Connectors (For temp sensors, optional)  If you can solder SMD, there’s a PCB available. These may be available pre-soldered in the future.

title: CLI
content: Prerequisites  Go 1.12+  Running Locally flowcontrol-cli cd src/flowcontrol-cli/ go install flowctl

title: PCB
content: Prerequisites  KiCAD 5.1 OpenSCAD  KiCAD 5.1 was used to the design the PCB and the board outline was designed using OpenSCAD.

title: Firmware
content: Prerequisites  Micro USB Cable  Flash firmware to the RPI Pico using your favourite IDE (VSCode, Thonny)
